rows.title: Why can't I store a value and a reference to that value in the same struct?
How do I detect a click outside an element?
What is the difference between "INNER JOIN" and "OUTER JOIN"?
How do I detect collision in pygame?

281:
<p>Inside the Sprite class, try adding a <code>self.mask</code> attribute with<br>
<code>self.mask = pygame.mask.from_surface(self.image)</code><br>
and a <code>collide_mask</code> function inside of the Sprite class with this code:</p>
<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python">    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">collide_mask</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, mask</span>):
        collided = <span class="hljs-literal">False</span>
        mask_outline = mask.outline()
        self.mask_outline = self.mask.outline()
        <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> point <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">range</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">len</span>(mask_outline)):
            mask_outline[point] = <span class="hljs-built_in">list</span>(mask_outline[point])
            mask_outline[point][<span class="hljs-number">0</span>] += bullet.x
            mask_outline[point][<span class="hljs-number">1</span>] += bullet.y
        <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> point <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">range</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">len</span>(self.mask_outline)):
            self.mask_outline[point] = <span class="hljs-built_in">list</span>(mask_outline[point])
            self.mask_outline[point][<span class="hljs-number">0</span>] += self.x
            self.mask_outline[point][<span class="hljs-number">1</span>] += self.y
        <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> point <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> mask_outline:
            <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> self_mask_point <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> self.mask_outline:
                <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> point = self_mask_point:
                    collided = <span class="hljs-literal">True</span>
        <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> collided
</code></pre>
282:
<p>Basically, in the first example you're binding the <code>i</code> inside the <code>onclick</code> handler directly to the <code>i</code> outside the <code>onclick</code> handler.  So when the <code>i</code> outside the <code>onclick</code> handler changes, the <code>i</code> inside the <code>onclick</code> handler changes too.</p>

<p>In the second example, instead of binding it to the <code>num</code> in the <code>onclick</code> handler, you're passing it into a function, which then binds it to the <code>num</code> in the <code>onclick</code> handler.  When you pass it into the function, the value of <code>i</code> is <em>copied, not bound</em> to <code>num</code>.  So when <code>i</code> changes, <code>num</code> stays the same.  The copy occurs because functions in JavaScript are "closures", meaning that once something is passed into the function, it's "closed" for outside modification.</p>
283:
<p>A inner join only shows rows if there is a matching record on the other (right) side of the join.</p>

<p>A (left) outer join shows rows for each record on the left hand side, even if there are no matching rows on the other (right) side of the join. If there is no matching row, the columns for the other (right) side would show NULLs.</p>
284:
<p>Check the window click event target (it should propagate to the window, as long as it's not captured anywhere else), and ensure that it's not any of the menu elements.  If it's not, then you're outside your menu.</p>

<p>Or check the position of the click, and see if it's contained within the menu area.</p>
